title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". The Congress finds that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit spread globally, prompting the Federal Reserve to respond to the financial crisis. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by establishing a Federal funds rate target range of 0 to 0.25 percent in December 2008, acknowledging the severity of the crisis and acting under "unusual and exigent circumstances" 11 times. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by setting a Federal funds rate target range of 0 to 0.25 percent in December 2008, citing "unusual and exigent circumstances" 11 times. The Board of Governors extended assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959 in efforts to address the crisis. During the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981. They also established joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America, implementing the Term Asset-Backed Securities Lending Facility, and launching the Public-Private Partnership Investment Program. Chairman Ben Bernanke emphasized transparency in his testimony on February 10, 2009. The Federal Reserve emphasized transparency in its lending programs and balance sheet during the financial crisis, as stated by Chairman Ben Bernanke in his testimony to the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 allows the Board or any Federal reserve bank to establish credit facilities for temporary assistance to private institutions as the lender of last resort. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes credit facilities including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, Commercial Paper Funding Facility, and Term Securities Lending Facility. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes various credit facilities, including Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, Maiden Lane III, LLC, the Revolving Credit Facility, reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles for credit facilities. The Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 authorizes credit facilities for various activities, with a termination clause after five years. A report on each review must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of completion. The report shall include findings, conclusions, and recommendations for action by the Comptroller General. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records.--Section 714(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to grant the Comptroller General access to officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility established by an agency upon request. The Comptroller General can make and retain copies of records as needed. The Comptroller General can access and make copies of records as deemed appropriate. Section 714(d)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include access to copies of records and credit facilities established by an agency.
